titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tiger's Eye Records
titlestmt.author: by Clayton McGahee and Ellen Doon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:59

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The records document all aspects of the production and distribution of the little magazine The Tiger's Eye, from its inception in 1947 through the decision to cease publication in 1951. Correspondence, manuscripts, and business records document the creative and editorial process, the enthusiasm of its readership, its subscription base, and the work involved in producing and distributing the issues.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Ruth and John Stephan, 1958; Gift of Ruth W. Franklin, 1971.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Tiger's Eye Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tiger's Eye Records. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. The arrangement of the material reflects the order of the files as they were acquired by the library. Much of the processing was done by library staff in the 1960s; final housing and description were completed in 2010.

bioghist.head: The Tiger's Eye (1947-1949)
bioghist.p: The little magazine The Tiger's Eye was founded in New York in 1947 by the poet Ruth Walgreen Stephan (1910-1974) and her husband, the painter John Stephan (1906-1995), and in its short existence earned acclaim for its discerning exposure of contemporary art and literature. Taking its title from William Blake, the magazine published the work of artists and writers both established and unknown, and documented the New York art world as well as international art movements, with particular emphasis on abstract expressionism. Its editorial selection process was based on the questions, "Is it alive? Is it valid as art? How brave is its originality? How does it enter the imagination?" (Issue 1, October 1947). The magazine did not publish reviews, and content was presented without immediate attribution so that readers could experience the works without preconception, although a list of contributors was included. Each issue was organized around a theme, such as modern sculpture, Peruvian art, or "the sublime."

The Tiger's Eye was published in nine quarterly issues between October 1947 and October 1949, when publication was suspended because the work became too much for the Stephans to manage. They initially intended to bring out further issues, but by 1951 realized that it would not be possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records document all aspects of the production and distribution of the little magazine The Tiger's Eye , from its inception in 1947 through the decision to cease publication in 1951. Correspondence, manuscripts, and business records document the creative and editorial process, the enthusiasm of its readership, its subscription base, and the work involved in producing and distributing the issues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1939-1955. II. Index Cards, 1947-1951. III. Manuscripts, 1947-1949. IV. Business Records, 1947-1951. V. 1971 Addition, 1946-1951.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized into six subseries: Correspondence with Authors, General Correspondence, Correspondence regarding Distribution, Correspondence regarding Subscriptions, Correspondence with Subscription Agents, and Correspondence with Booksellers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence documents the editorial work of the magazine, including solicitation of content, and the business of distribution to individual subscribers, agents, booksellers. Outgoing carbon copies of letters from the Stephans, their associate editors, and their staff are frequently present in the files. Correspondence from contributors occasionally includes manuscripts. The General Correspondence subseries includes a mix of inquries about contributions, rejections, and exchanges with potential subscribers, as well as blank stationery, ephemera concerning art exhibitions, and other miscellaneous material. Correspondence regarding Distribution includes orders for single issues and distribution of complimentary copies, and documents the suspension of publication and refunds given in 1949 through 1951. Correspondence regarding subcriptions, with agents, and with booksellers documents individual subcribers to the magazine as well as the venues in which it was available for sale.
Additional correspondence can be found in Series IV. Business Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Index cards consist of three separate index files. The largest is to the content of individual issues of the magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains typescript or holograph drafts of textual content of issues 1-8. For issue 9, this material is present along with proofs and other material documenting production of that issue.

did.physloc: See also OversizePage proof - complete set (In Series III)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged according to original file headings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Business records include correspondence regarding personnel and transactions with banks, advertisers, printers, engravers, and other companies with which Tiger's Eye did business. It also includes bank statements, financial and subscription ledgers, and calendars documenting the receipt and return of material for the magazine. Financial documents concerning trust funds for Ruth Stephan's children by her first marriage are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V consists of correspondence, manuscripts, and notes that were not included in the original gift.
